Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: High Brightness Fluorophores for Bioscience Applications
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project will be to develop new fluorophores for use with flow cytometers to enable the detection and sorting of thousands of cells per second. The market opportunity for fluorophores that are important imaging reagents for biomedical research is significant and growing, and there is a growing demand for multi-color flow cytometers and other cell imaging technologies. The goal for this technology is to simplify the design and reduce the cost of next generation flow cytometers, enhance the attraction and popularity of flow cytometry by simplifying the operation procedures and reducing the ownership cost, create new market opportunity for flow cytometry manufacturers (instrument, and reagents), and enable wide spread use of flow cytometry in clinical labs that would promote more effective diagnosis of health disorders and thus allow earlier treatments. This STTR Phase I project proposes to create a platform technology that can enhance the fluorescence brightness of fluorophores by blocking the fluorescent quenching pathways. Ideally, the proposed technology would offer enhanced fluorescent brightness up to 250-1,000 times of existing fluorophores. The goal is to enhance the detection efficiency of flow cytometry by overcoming the drawback of spillover, reduce or eliminate the need of autofluorescence background compensation, enable scientists, engineers, and technicians to obtain better flow cytometry data at shorter overall durations, and allow the detection and sorting of low abundance cells especially those in stem cell research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Disease diagnosis is still challenging because many diseases share same set of symptoms. For example, 8 different symptoms mimics multiple sclerosis (MS), a disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body. Ideally, researchers need to be able to investigate various parameters in order to achieve accurate diseases diagnosis, especially at the molecular level. This would help scientist to diagnose patient at the early stage and establish preventive measures. Therefore, multi-parametric detection techniques are important for accurate disiease diagnosis.

Flow cytometry can detect and sort up to thousands of cells per second. This is a convenient multi-parametric biophysical technology to count, sort, and analyze cells based on laser-induced fluorescence signals from fluorophore tagged cells, suspended in a stream of flowing fluid. Each different types of cells in the sample present different marker which are specifically labeled with known fluorophore tagged antibodies for identification. Because of the high analysis efficiency, flow cytometry is widely used in clinical labs for HIV and blood cancer screening, as well as research facilities for cancer and stem cell research. In principle, flow cytometry would detect up to 18 different parameters simultaneously. In practice, 6-8 color flow cytometry are mostly used by researchers, in clinics 2 color flow cytometry are used due to limitations of reagents/fluorophores.

 Unfortunately, flow cytometry is limited by two major issues. The first issue is signal overlapping during multi-color detection (the so-called “spillover”). This issue is very serious especially for a dim signal from low abundance cells (says cancer or stem cells). Spillover will prevent the detection of such rare cells. The second issue is the inherent background fluorescence from various cell structures, the so-called “auto-fluorescence”. Auto-fluorescence might result in false positive signal since it is difficult to differentiate real signal from background signal. These issues could be partially resolved by a complicated signal analysis process which is not accurate. These problems could also be reduced by expensive instrument makeover by using optical filters and high-end detectors. According to industrial experts, all these issues can be resolved by using fluorophores that can emit brighter signals. The ultimate goal of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to create a platform technology for producing high-brightness of fluorophores that will resolve the above mentioned issues.

 

?Intellectual merits: This STTR Phase I project has successfully created a product that offer green fluorescent brightness that is more than 10 times brighter than those in commercially available fluorophores. Furthermore, this brightness is tunable to meet the needs of various cell population. Our success will enhance the detection efficiency of flow cytometry by overcoming the drawback of spillover, and eliminate the need of auto-fluorescence background compensation. Our success will also enable scientists, engineers, and technicians to obtain better data at shorter overall durations, and allow the detection and sorting of low abundance cells especially those in early cancer detection and stem cell research.

 

Broader Impacts: This STTR project has created a platform technology for producing high-brightness fluorophores that has high commercial values. Our target market is the rapidly growing multi-color flow cytometry sector. Our success will simplify the design and reduce the cost of next generation flow cytometers. This will enhance the attraction and popularity of flow cytometry by simplifying the operation procedures and reducing the ownership cost. We will create new market opportunity for flow cytometry manufacturers (instrument, and reagents), and enable wide spread use of flow cytometry in clinical labs that would promote more effective diagnosis of health disorders and thus allow earlier treatments.
